conclusion: To determine if the difference in speed between objects A and B (denoted as Δv = v_A - v_B) continuously increases over the time interval from 0 to t_1, we need to analyze the graph and the behavior of the curves.
Both objects start at rest, so their initial speeds are 0.

premise: Both objects start at rest, so their initial speeds are 0.

conclusion: v_A(t) reaches its maximum at some point before t_1. v_B(t) also reaches its maximum but at a lower value than v_A(t) and occurs after v_A(t) peaks. Both v_A(t) and v_B(t) decrease to zero again by t_1.

premise: The difference in speed Δv(t) = v_A(t) - v_B(t) can be positive, negative, or zero depending on the relative positions of the two curves.
conclusion: If v_A(t) > v_B(t), then Δv(t) > 0. Conversely, if v_A(t) < v_B(t), then Δv(t) < 0.

premise: The rate of change of Δv(t) depends on the slopes of v_A(t) and v_B(t).
conclusion: When both slopes are positive, Δv(t) could increase if v_A(t) increases faster than v_B(t). When both slopes are negative, Δv(t) could decrease if v_A(t) decreases slower than v_B(t).

premise: The slopes of v_A(t) and v_B(t) do not remain constant throughout the interval.
conclusion: The difference Δv(t) will not necessarily continuously increase or decrease. There will be instances where the difference in speed changes direction (from increasing to decreasing).

premise: The difference in speed between the two objects does not continuously increase over the time interval from 0 to t_1.
conclusion: The difference in speed will vary based on the changing slopes of the velocity-time graphs for objects A and B.
